comment: aki is a Nama loan, the original Komnzo word is zath but it is somewhat archaic
ŋäwi is somewhat archaic, babai is more commonly used

ama kitong means 'big mother', the term babale is an innovation among young people, extending from its original meaning of MBW. Once MZ marries out, (whether mMZ or fMZ, whether MeZ or MyZ) she gets renamed as yakal yadma 'yakal mother', her husband is kn
again, babale is an innovation among younger people from its original MBW meaning
ŋare (woman), often with a possessive prefix, eg. nzufzenz, nzuŋame `my wife'
ŋare (woman), often with a possessive prefix, eg. nzufzenz, nzuŋame `my wife'
kabe (man), often with a possessive prefix, eg. nzufis, nzukabe `my husband'
kabe (man), often with a possessive prefix, eg. nzufis, nzukabe `my husband'

This and the following terms are built around zath, aki 'grandkin', reckoning the affine from the point of view of the grandchild who is descended from both speaker and hearer. Then a further disambiguating word is added: ŋare 'woman, wife

choice between nane and ngth depends on relative age, as with sibling terms, ane being for older cousins in this category, ngth for younger. Same applies to all other cells for which nane and ngth are listed as alternatives

choice between nane and ngth depends on relative age, as with sibling terms, ane being for older cousins in this category, ngth for younger. Same applies to all other cells for which nane and ngth are listed as alternatives
yamit is only used if there was a consummated sister-exchange, i.e. the father has exchanged his sister
yamit is only used if there was a consummated sister-exchange, i.e. the father has exchanged his sister
special term if two women are sisters. their respective children called each other naku and treat one another like brothers/sister. the husbands of the two sisters called each other nakum
